Award.AwardTitle: Research in Quantum Field and String Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research explores connections between gauge theory and quantum aspects of gravitational physics, particularly the concept of emergent geometry and emergent strings in the AdS/CFT correspondence.
Some of the topics to be studied are aspects of higher dimensional geometry as seen from gauge theory. Part of this program is to study states that preserve some supersymmetries. The other part is to study non-commutative structures. The PI will focus on aspects of integrability in Yang Mills theories. The PI is also interested in exploring the non-commutative Geometric Aspects of emergent gravity in gauge theory. He plans to work on various condensed matter physics problems where the phase transitions are of a topological nature. Using topological quantum field theory techniques, the PI proposes to study the properties of graphenes and the spin Hall effect. As to the broader impacts, The PI has several collaborators in China and in the Asia-Pacific region. Support of ongoing collaborations with them will make it possible to bring top students, postdocs and professors, including those from under-served demographic groups and those from Asia Pacific and Latin America, to Utah, to promote international exchange of scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is a mulitdisciplinary research on fundamental laws of the physical world around us. On the one hand, these laws are those governing the behavior of elementary particles at the smallest distances that we can detect presently. On the other hand, the laws are also deeply relevant to understanding the origin, composition and evolution of our universe.

The research done in this project constists of two parts. The outcomes of one part of the research deal with mathematical strutures in the underlying theoretical framework that accounts for all fundamental interactions of elementary particles. Particular atttention is paid to the unification of two cornerstones of 20th century physics -- one (quantum theory) addressing the dynamics of particles and forces at the subnuclear scales and the other (Einstein's general relativity) addressing the forces and laws of matter at the cosmological scales. The other part of the research applies the knowledge and techniques we have learned from the theory of elementary particle physics to the study of the novel collective behavior of (quantum) many-particle systems at low temperatures, which gives rise to a number of exotic new states of matter even at daily-life scales. Better understanding of these new states of matter may lead to inventing new devices or technical advances in communication and computation as semiconductors and electronics did. Also it may have a great impact on our undestanding of the physical laws at the most fundamental level, because ultimately our unvierse is a quantum many-particle system from a contemporary point of view.

The findings of the project can be briefly summarized as follows. First in our study of the fundamental laws, we have developed a new mathematical formulation for the effective description of the fundamental objects -- multiple membranes -- in the so-called M-theory, believed to be a theoretical frameowrk that can unify all fundamental interactions (including gravity), as well as various string theories as its special cases. The mathematical structure underlying our new approach is called 3-algebras, a generalization of the mathematical structure that underlies the Standard Model, that summarizes the present knowledge on the presently known particles and their interactions except gravity. Secondly, we have studied a fundamental and mysterious aspect -- entanglement -- of the quantum dynamics that governs the collective behavior of the contituent particles of the world around us. Some discrete models have been previously proposed to describe a wide class of novel states of matter, the so-called toplogical matter, whose formation is essentially due to long-range entanglement. We have been able to do computations for certain properties in these models, which have never been done before and led to new insights for better understanding the pattern of long-range entanglement -- in the context of holography -- in the toplogical states of matter. We have also studied a possible application -- the so-called braiding gates -- of the ideas in topology, an old branch in mathematics, to quantum computation or information processing, a new frontier of computer science that expoits quantum features of fundamental dynamics of particles for the purpose of doing computation and/or communication. Moreover, colloborating with Professor Dong-Sheng Guo (Southern University, Barton Rouge, Louisanna), we have been able to find the exact solutions for the fundamental model in atomic physics, namely a
two-level atom in the monochoromatic light field. With our exact solutions, we suggest a method of detremining the intensity of a strong laser beam by measuring the atomic energy shift.
